title: Example-Analysis
text: methodological package developed R analyzing submitted article: Aguirre-Villaseñor, H., Morales-Bojórquez, E., Cisneros-Mata (FISH13711). Biometric relationships fisheries management tool: case study bullseye puffer (Sphoeroides annulatus. Tetraodontidae). Fisheries Research. fisheries monitoring, body length commonly measured parameter quick easy obtain. contrast, measuring weight requires level stable scale, can difficult secure field sampling. Biometric relationships crucial fisheries biology. accurately calculated, relationships can useful management purposes, especially estimating organism’s total length weight based body measurements. Many species marketed artisanal fishing various commercial forms. However, currently biometric relationships allow predicting live weight (total weight fish) different categories landed weight, fillet weight, gutted weight, frozen weight. objective package provide quantitative analysis various morphological relationships help predict: ) expected live weight different landed weight categories, b) expected fillet yield various commercial presentations, c) testing suitability fillet yield reference point managing target species. purpose, functions vignette created explain process step step. implementation streamlines methodology enhances clarity impact results graphical presentations (tables figures personalized). functions included Morefi package enable evaluation length-length, weight-weight length-weight biometric relationships using data exhibit high variability meet assumptions necessary adjustment via least squares. Given variability, robust regression method employed analysis. “robustbase” package (version 0.99-2) utilized fit robust regression models, using functions lmrob() linear nlrob() non-linear regression (Maechler et al., 2024).

text: function fn_ARSS() perform Coincident Curves Test, determine significant differences fitted curves database. based Analysis Residual Sum Squares (ARSS) (Chen et al. 1992). F=RSSp−RSSs3•(K−1)RSSsN−3•KF=\frac{\frac{RSS_{p}-RSS_{s}}{3\bullet \left( K-1 \right)}}{\frac{RSS_{s}}{N-3\bullet K}} RSSp=RSSRSS_{p}= RSS regression fitted pooled data, RSSsRSS_{s}= sum RSSRSS regression fitted individual sample, NN= total sample size, KK = number samples comparison. residual sum squares RSSRSS degrees freedom DFDF fitted regression previously stored List_TCCT list. regression, calculations stored data frame T1, stored iteratively using loop list T. Inside function, RSS DF joined sample calculated perform F test two tails α/2\alpha/2. decision criteria performed: “*” p−value≤αp-value\le \alpha “NS” p−val>αp-val\gt \alpha. function requires defining: List_TCCT: list fitted regression results. : integer value indicating ith regression analyzed. alfa: numerical value defines significance level. default number 0.05. function return data frame containing results Coincident Curves Test stored list.

text: function calculates robust version coefficient determination RRV2R^{2}_{RV} using Equation Summary values fitted robustbase::nlrob() function. consistency corrected robust coefficient determination Renaud Victoria-Feser (2010) allows possible correction factor consistency considerations. Inside function: vectors observed (y1), predicted (yc) weighted (W) values obtained summary model (eq). value Weighted Estimate Average (ywea), modified sum squares explained (SSEw), total (SSTw), residual (SSRw) estimated. correction factor value consistency considerations 95 percent also obtained summary model (eq). vector robust version coefficient determination R2wa adjusted value R2wa_adj returned vector. function, following estimated: Weighted Estimate Average ŷ¯w\overline{\widehat{y}}_{w} (called ywea). ŷ¯w=(1/Σwi)×Σwiŷ\overline{\widehat{y}}_{w}=\left(1/\Sigma w_{}\right)\times \Sigma w_{} \widehat{y}_{} modified sum squares explained SSEw SSEw=∑wi(ŷ−ŷ¯w)2)SSEw= \sum_{}^{}w_{}(\widehat{y}_{}-\overline{\widehat{y}}_{w}) ^2) function, robust residual standard error (RSER)(RSE_{R}) utilized, modified sum squared residuals computed SSRwSSRw. SSRw=df*(RSER)2)SSRw= df* (RSE_{R})^2) variables (RSER)(RSE_{R}) dfdf (degrees freedom) obtained model summary. robust version coefficient determination Rw,a2R^{2}_{w,}Rw,a2=SSEwSSEw+×SSRwR^{2}_{w,}=\frac{SSEw}{SSEw+\times SSRw} adjusted coefficient determination Radj,w,a2R^{2}_{adj,w,}Radj,w,a2=1−(1−Rw,a2)×(n−1n−q)R^{2}_{adj,w,}=1- \left(1- R^{2}_{w,}\right)\times \left( \frac{n-1 }{n-q} \right) y1iy1_{}, ŷ\widehat{y}_{} ithi_{th} observed predicted values, aa correction factor value consistency considerations 95 percent, nn number pairs observations qq number variables included model. function requires defining: eq Summary equation fitted using robustbase::nlrob() function. function returns vector robust version coefficient determination Rw,a2R^{2}_{w,} adjusted value Radj,w,a2R^{2}_{adj,w,}.

title: Example-Analysis
text: objecteq2 originates example fn_dfa(). [1] 0.9805933 0.9805794
code: eq <- eq2   fn_R2RV <- function(eq){   w <- eq$rweights   # w a vector of weights values   yc <- eq$fitted.values # yc a vector of predicted values   ywea <-  (1/sum(w)) * sum(w*yc) # a value of the Weighted Estimate Average   df <- summary(eq)$df[2]   SSEw <- sum(w*(yc-ywea)^2)   SSRw <- (eq2[["Scale"]]^2)*df   a <- environment(eq[["psi"]])[["cc"]]   R2wa <- SSEw/(SSEw+a*SSRw)   R2wa_adj <- 1-(1-R2wa)*((length(yc)-1)/df)   R2was <- c(R2wa,R2wa_adj)   print(R2was) }    w <- eq$rweights   # w a vector of weights values   yc <- eq$fitted.values # yc a vector of predicted values   ywea <-  (1/sum(w)) * sum(w*yc) # a value of the Weighted Estimate Average   y1 <- eq$model[,1]   SSEw <- sum(w*(yc-ywea)^2)   SSRw <- eq[["Scale"]]   a <- environment(eq[["psi"]])[["cc"]]   R2wa <- SSEw/(SSEw+(a*SSRw))   R2wa_adj <- 1-(1-R2wa)*((length(y1)-1)/summary(eq)$df[2])   R2was <- c(R2wa,R2wa_adj)   print(R2was) #> [1] 0.9999995 1.0000000

title: Morefi
text: function fn_ARSS() perform Coincident Curves Test, determine significant differences fitted curves database. based Analysis Residual Sum Squares (ARSS) (Chen et al. 1992). F=RSSp−RSSs3•(K−1)RSSsN−3•KF=\frac{\frac{RSS_{p}-RSS_{s}}{3\bullet \left( K-1 \right)}}{\frac{RSS_{s}}{N-3\bullet K}} RSSp=RSSRSS_{p}= RSS regression fitted pooled data, RSSsRSS_{s}= sum RSSRSS regression fitted individual sample, NN= total sample size, KK = number samples comparison. residual sum squares RSSRSS degrees freedom DFDF fitted regression previously stored List_TCCT list. regression, calculations stored data frame T1, stored iteratively using loop list T. Inside function, RSS DF joined sample calculated perform F test two tails α/2\alpha/2. decision criteria performed: “*” p−value≤αp-value\le \alpha “NS” p−val>αp-val\gt \alpha. function requires defining: List_TCCT: list fitted regression results. : integer value indicating ith regression analyzed. alfa: numerical value defines significance level. default number 0.05. function return data frame containing results Coincident Curves Test stored list.

text: Using biometric data Morefi::botete, linear relationship Total Length Standard Length (LT_LS) established using robustbase::lmrob function. title: Morphological Relationships Fitted by Robust Regression
text: Morefi package: Morphological Relationships Fitted Robust Regression. methodological package developed R analyze submitted article: Aguirre-Villaseñor, H., Morales-Bojórquez, E., Cisneros-Mata (FISH13711). Biometric relationships fisheries management tool: case study bullseye puffer (Sphoeroides annulatus. Tetraodontidae). Fisheries Research. fisheries monitoring, body length commonly measured parameter quick easy obtain. contrast, measuring weight requires level stable scale, can difficult secure field sampling. Biometric relationships crucial fisheries biology. accurately calculated, relationships can useful management purposes, especially estimating organism’s total length weight based body measurements. Many species marketed artisanal fishing various commercial forms. However, currently biometric relationships allow predicting live weight (total weight fish) different categories landed weight, fillet weight, gutted weight, frozen weight. objective package provide quantitative models various morphological relationships help predict: ) expected live weight different landed weight categories, b) expected fillet yield various commercial presentations, c) testing suitability fillet yield reference point managing target species. purpose, functions vignette created explain process step step. implementation streamlines methodology enhances clarity impact results graphical presentations (tables figures personalized). functions included Morefi package enable evaluation length-length, weight-weight length-weight biometric relationships using data exhibit high variability meet assumptions necessary adjustment via least squares. Given variability, robust regression method employed analysis. “robustbase” package (version 0.99-2) utilized fit robust regression models, using functions lmrob() linear nlrob() non-linear regression (Maechler et al., 2024).

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # The Total length (LT) - Total weight (WT) was estimated for the bullseye puffer # *Sphoeroides annulatus* for landed categories: Fresh, Frozen-thawed (Frozen), Total # (All sample) and Joined (sum of values of Fresh and Frozen). The Residual Sum of # Squares (RSS) and the degrees of freedom (DF) are provided for each data source. # In the table the first row displays the Analysis of Residual Sum of Squares (ARSS), # the p-value (p), and the decision criteria for the ARSS test (Criteria).  # The adjusted models show the following data: Fresh SSR=   and DF= 742; Frozen # SSR= 1280131.81 and DF= 651; and the total sample SSR= 6115874.53 and DF= 1395. # Values are stored in the table `Table_CC`, this is stored in a list, and the name # of each item is built with the acronyms of the model variables (e.g. LTWT).  Table_CC <- data.frame(matrix(NA,nrow=4,ncol=8)) Table_CC[1,1] <- "Lt-WT" Table_CC[,2] <- c("Fresh","Frozen","Total","Joined") colnames(Table_CC) <- c("Model","Category","RSS","DF","ARSS","F-table","p-value","Criteria")  Table_CC[1,3] <- 4424418.33 Table_CC[1,4] <-  742 Table_CC[2,3] <- 1280131.81 Table_CC[2,4] <-  651 Table_CC[3,3] <- 6115874.53 Table_CC[3,4] <-  1395  List_ARSS <- list(LTWT=Table_CC)  i <- 1  ARSS <- fn_ARSS(List_ARSS, i,  alfa= 0.05) ARSS[[i]] } # }
